creditline: Gift of funds from Lucy Mitchell
description: irregular shaped photo with two black-and-white images of eroded hillsides; a bright red 4-sided shape is at the center between the two black-and-white images; face mounted to acrylic; rectangular wood cleat adhered to verso
markings: paper sticker label at BR verso: Michael Namingha, 2019 / Black Place #1 / Digital C-Print Face Mounted to Shaped Acrylic / 28 x 40 x 1 in / Edition of 3 / Artist Proof
medium: Digital chromogenic print face-mounted to shaped acrylic
signed: paper sticker label at BR verso: Michael Namingha
text: As scholar and curator Jami Powell notes, “During a 2017 residency at the Georgia O’Keeffe Museum  in Santa Fe, New Mexico, Michael Namingha found  himself drawn to the distinct, rounded, gray-and-black  terrain of the Bistahí Dééł Náázíní (Bisti/De-Na-Zin  Wilderness), which O’Keeffe called the “Black Place.” The area sits beneath the largest methane cloud in the United  States, which when viewed with infrared technology appears as a bright orange, red, and yellow dot over the  Four Corners region. After using a drone to capture the image of the fragile landscape, Namingha arranged the red from this satellite imagery alongside the fragmented and abstracted landscape. The result is a hauntingly beautiful interrogation of human intervention on the landscape.”
title: Black Place #1
